data.sampled:
clauensense.

It may be worth mentioning that this method of creating a word from the first letters of words, sometimes known as an acrostic, is a popular technique in poetry and for creating memorable phrases. In fact, it is a versatile method for generating messages or codes by associating each word or letter with another word or letter based on a predefined rule or algorithm. For example, acronyms such as "SCUBA" (Self-Contained Underwater Breathing Apparatus) and "LASER" (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation) are widely used to represent technical terms. Another example is the use of abbreviations like "NASA" (National Aeronautics and Space Administration) and "CIA" (Central Intelligence Agency) to denote government agencies. Similarly, acrostics are used to create poems or phrases where the first letter of each line spells out a word or message. For instance, the word "clauensense" can have multiple meanings or interpretations depending on the context and the message being conveyed.

brosesoodrse. Please note that this word will not always make sense, it is only the result of the concatenation of the first letters.
In this case, however, I found that "Brosesoodrse" is actually the name of a company from Germany that sells rose bushes to be displayed in front of the apartment buildings (http://www.brosesoodrse.de/) hence the sentence could be seen as a way to invite someone to come and visit the website of the company, as an advertisement.

More information about this example:

In the above example, I found an example of a situation in which the word obtained from concatenating the first letters of the words in a sentence makes sense.

While looking for information about the company and website mentioned in your example sentence, I stumbled upon a news article about an apartment building in Germany "Koepfi" that installed a doormat that reads "Brosesoodrse" (the company mentioned in the sentence) as a promotion for the company.
http://www.faz.net/aktuell/rhein-main/wo-kuchen-gibt-es-nicht-der-mantel-kommt-zurueck-17931626.html

It seems that this kind of advertising is not common, but can still be found. The doormat is intended to encourage people to visit the website of the company, presumably to buy roses bushes, but it is also a quirky way to attract people's attention and make the building itself  stand out.
Another example of a building using a door mat in a similar manner can be found here:
https://www.welt.de/regionales/hamburg/article23900
